intro: Lythrum borysthenicum subsp. hispidulum, commonly known as the hispid lupine, is a flowering plant native to the steppes of Eastern Europe and Central Asia. It is a herbaceous perennial that typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring upright stems covered in fine, stiff hairs. The plant produces spikes of pink to purple flowers, which bloom from late spring to early summer. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and often have a hairy texture, contributing to its distinctive appearance. This subspecies is adapted to dry, sandy soils and is often found in open habitats such as grasslands and disturbed areas.
